Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 02:33PM Lifeafter wrote: I am a stomach sleeper too.  My BMX was this past June.  I had immediate reconstruction, one TE removed a month later due to infection and replaced this past October.  I am just now able to sleep on my sides.  Like others, I need a pillow for support against my chest and a pillow between my legs. I slept upright in my bed for about two to three weeks after the BMX and about a week after the TE replacement.  My brother took my bed apart, with just the matresses on the floor.  There was no way I was able to get into my bed (it's high).  But having the mattresses on the ground was great.  It was easier for me to get in and out and easier for people to help me also.  I had a couple big square stiff pillows up against the wall and others as needed for support for sleeping and such.  I had all size pillows for whatever the situation called for: a small stiff square one for my lower/mid back when laying down, softer pillow to prop against the larger stiff ones when lying back, etc. My bed was put back together after one of my TE's was taken out.  I had a small step with a couple of steps up against my bed so I could get in.  Even though I had the other surgery a month after my BMX, I was still able to get up and down my bed easily.  It was nice to have my bed back to normal. You're lucky you've got a some time ahead of you to plan.  Good luck! Michelle :-)
Posts.Title: Sleeping after Surgery mary625 Outfield

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 02:37PM Lifeafter wrote: Might I add, you know how in the morning you get that urge to stretch when you wake up?  Don't!  Once I started to ween off the drugs and was not in a zombie state, I woke up and forgot.  I did a big stretch...big mistake.  Resist that urge until you are able to sneeze normally without having to clutch you chest or hold it in. This was my experience.  I'm sure I'm not the only one. Michelle :-)
Posts.Title: Sleeping after Surgery mary625 Outfield

Posts.Content: Lifeafter wrote: I had a bilateral mastectomy in late June.  Late July I had an infection in my chest and the right tissue expander had to be removed.  The right tissue expander was replaced in late October.  After I started to heal from the July surgery, I noticed that if I touched sertain areas on my chest where my boobs used to be, I would 'feel' it in my upper arm.  I have had funny 'electrical' sensations in the same spots in my arms by not doing anything.  After the October surgery if I press on those same areas in my chest, the immediate sensation I feel in my arms is stronger.  I don't feel in the area I push on on my chest.  It's like, I'm not touching my chest but those areas in my upper arms.  It's on both sides.  It's really weird.  I told my PS about it cause I was curious what was going on.  He had never heard of that before. Anyone have this happen?  I'm not worried, it's just weird! 5/5/11 lumpectomy - 5/13/11 PMX - 6/20/11 BMX w/immediate recon 7/27/11 RT TE removed - 10/28/11 RT TE replaced - 2/3/12 oopherectomy/salpingectomy - 7/3/12 major revision, LFT implant - 9/7/12 RT Implant Dx 5/12/2011, DCIS, 3cm, Stage 0, Grade 3, 1/3 nodes, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Lifeafter wrote: Hi, I posted in here a few months ago when my biopsy report came back that I had atypical cells.  I really wasn't worried but since then, they did the lumpectomy and it came back cancer.  They went back in a week later and did a partial mastectomy.  Again, thought everything was going to be fine but...they didn't get it all and could not get clear margins.  I could go the radiation route with tamoxiphen but the dr and oncologist said, it more than liekly wouldn't be enough.  So I said fine, take it off.  It's ok with me.  Since this all started back in August when I had my very first mammogram at the age of 39 and they saw these abnormalities they said...it's most like ly nothing but we need to watch it.  Well six months later the stuff multiplied, they still said it's most likely nothing only a small percentage of woman end up having cancer.  Well after each appointment and procedure and surgery, they always come back..with a well...guess what.  The radiologist finding what they did was like finding a needle in the haystack the very first time and how lucky I am.  Yeah, I get it but who's to say there isn't a needle in the haystack in my left breast.  And...when they go in they don't find an invasive cancer hiding?  I already am set that that's what they'll find.  I'm prepared and am ok, just really frustrated at this point.  I like things now and am very impatient.  I have a consult with the plastic surgeon in a week, my surgeon will see if I can get in sooner.  And then after that they will coordinate times and schedule my surgery for the double mastectomy.  I am finding I have an somewhat of an extensive history of breast cancer in my family and I'm not going to chance it.  They're only boobs and they'll make new ones for me.  I'm just really tired.  Two surgeries in the past 2 1/2 weeks and now this one.  I forgot to add that the surgeon has told me that the cancer has grown fast, it has spread through-out a large area of my breast (they took half during the partial) and it of course is still there.  Can anyone tell me what to expect for recovery time?  I don't like to sit, it's been hell these being out these past three weeks.  What will my strength be like after?  My surgeon says him and the pastic surgeon do reconstruction in on procedure.  I'm hearing a lot of different stories.  I need to know what to ask the plastic surgeon when I have my consult.  Thank you so much.  Michelle 5/5/11 lumpectomy - 5/13/11 PMX - 6/20/11 BMX w/immediate recon 7/27/11 RT TE removed - 10/28/11 RT TE replaced - 2/3/12 oopherectomy/salpingectomy - 7/3/12 major revision, LFT implant - 9/7/12 RT Implant Dx 5/12/2011, DCIS, 3cm, Stage 0, Grade 3, 1/3 nodes, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: High Grade DCIS - Full Mastectomy Lifeafter Lifeafter

Posts.Content: May 23, 2011 02:19PM Lifeafter wrote: Blah, that's what I was starting to think.  Crap.  I had in my head I'll be good to go after a couple with weeks!  I have two daughters but they are 16 1/2 and 19.  My oldest will be coming home from college in two weeks and my youngest is finishing up her junior year of high school.  So we are gearing up for college.  It's just me and my girls.  It's been hardest on my youngest because she is home and I've had to rely on her for help.  I forgot to mention that our dog was injured a month and a half ago and is paralyzed in the rear.  It's been a torturous past couple of months for us.  Between his doctor appointments and mine plus my surgeries she is wearing thin.  I'm lucky my coworkers have brought me meals so i haven't had to worry about cooking for her and I have plenty of aunts in my family who have been in and out of my house.  One who has been there almost everyday caring for me and my dog.  But you can see why recovery is my main concern.  I don't want to be a burden on anyone expecially my daughters.  I want them to have their summer.  Especially my youngest who always seems to get the short end of the stick.  My oldest almost died three years ago of necrotizing pneumonia, it was a wait and see if she would make it and once again my youngest had to give up stuff because I couldn't take her or help was needed.  It really sucks.  Blah blah blah...I could go on but we all have our sob stories.  My plastic surgeon just called and moved my consult to the 2nd!  Augh!  So am I really looking at 6 to 8 weeks?  I have to fill out paperwork for work for cautastrophic leave, cause I sure don't have that kind of vacation and sick time.  I've used most of it up for this past month I've been out.  I will definitely ask for PT, I didn't think of that!
Posts.Title: High Grade DCIS - Full Mastectomy Lifeafter Lifeafter

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2012 02:22PM Lifeafter wrote: I have a question...I bought minoxydil.  Now I'm thinking I really meant to buy Nioxin but got confused.  Ugh.  Should I have bought minoxydil?  I did not have chemo but lost a lot of hair because my body was so stressed from multiple surgeries.  I lost it from the top of my head up front where my scalp meets my forehead.  I've been putting it on twice a day for the past couple of weeks. I naturally have very sparse eyebrows and use Anastasia.  It's really good stuff and looks much more natural than pencil.  Although I have a pencil I bought that is very good because I couldn't get into Sephora to get more Anastasia.  I got the pencil at Sally's Beauty Supply. It's called Brow Couture by Femme Couture.  It's very soft and you can feather it on nicely and it stays on.  They have a was pencil that you can buy to go with it to put it over to give it staying power but I have found I don't need it. Michelle

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 08:49PM Lifeafter wrote: I had my BMX in June '11.  I reached my 6 month mark a couple weeks ago.  It is a gradual thing you get used to.  In the beginning, I was paranoid about protecting my chest.  I had my right TE removed a month after BMX due to an infection.  It was put back in right before Halloween.  So just when I got used to my chest and going about life, I was right back to protecting it and being aware of it again.  With each surgery, it got easier.  I don't wear a prosthesis, like others I hated them.  So uncomfortable!  Someone mentioned something about having a concave chest if you don't wear them.  The lady at the prosthesis store told me that too.  The prosthesis make you aware to stand up straight and not hunch.  I think that's probably what they are alluding too.  Just be aware and keep your shoulders back, you know that old 'stand up straight!' routine. I don't wear a sports bra, no point, I'm still pretty flat, lumpy but flat.  My TEs aren't full yet to where it would be needed.  It is nice to just throw a shirt on! I went through bouts of depression, it's normal.  I would have your vitamin levels checked.  You have to ask I have found.  My Vit D levels were extremely low along with Vit B.  Those are important in your body recovering and your mental health.  I'm taking B12 shots now, what a difference it makes, and Vit D (50000iu a week).  Vit D was prescribed, I take one pill a week. It does take time. Don't rush yourself as hard as that may be.  We want to feel our normal selves again and as much as you may not want to get yet.  We will not be our normal selves for sometime, if ever.  We had a big part of our womanhood taken from us and unlike a man having a testicle removed ours is right out there for everyone to see. My suggestion is give in to something that makes you feel good.  Get your hair done, get a massage...there are tables with holes for your chest (you can even just have one on your back).  get your hands, legs and feet massaged. You so deserve it. Don't do things that will cause you to feel like crap. For me, it's still trying on clothes.  They don't fit right and look awful. I'll stick with jeans and tshirts for now. After I get my weight back off and have my exchange, I'll get back into the dressing rooms. I hope this helps you. :) Michelle
Posts.Title: processing what just happened lynliz mebmarj

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 02:09PM Lifeafter wrote: DrBabs - I was the one that advised her on that.  I told her that she may want to get a stack of inexpensive wash cloths from Walmart and have them in the bathroom with her - just in case.  I told her my experience was that I was not able to do that for almost two weeks. I didn't say she wouldn't be able to but to take note on those positions now.  Arm movement is limited after surgery and it could be difficult.  I had those on hand for help and they came in very handy. Michelle

Posts.Content: Lifeafter wrote: Hi, Been awhile since I posted. Has anyone had a white puss filled pimple pop up on their mastectomy scar a couple years post mastectomy? I did about a week ago. It was/is near the where my nipple was about an inch off. I popped it and a lot of puss came out. Then it formed a hard nodule. It stayed raised for awhile like there was more still in it. I would keep squeezing it to no avail, it's finally gone down but it's still hard. It's about the size of a pencil eraser. I did get my areolas tattooed five weeks ago. I thought maybe that was it but odd that it would be that long after the procedure. I made an appointment with my breast surgeon, I need to have a followup for more 'fixit' stuff. But I don't see her for two weeks.
